content: Broken and full of bugs. If it didn't cost over ¬£17 to get all expansions of the game, it wouldn't matter. 1. The animations take forever, between 5-10 seconds per go. So if you play a 110 tile game you'll spend up to nine minutes watching animations while your clock ticks down. 2. Your clock also ticks down around five seconds before you can take your turn, which eats another four minutes of your game. 3. My score goes down sometimes when I win or when it fails to register a win. 4. Games are timed except the penalty for your opponent running out of time is that the computer takes over for them. Nothing worse than someone running out of time and then still winning. The computer isn't on a timer so you can wait a few minutes for it to make a move but you have to be ready to take your turn as your timer will still tick down. 5. There is a karma system to penalise people quitting games, but it doesn't stop them not taking their turn and forcing you to have wait until the timer runs out or quitting yourself. 6. Not enough people have expansions because of cost so hard to play ranked games online with them. 7. You can't continue chatting with your opponent once the game ends and the search for a user function is broken. 8. If it's obvious you can't win, forfeiting the game loses you karma, so you're best to just stop playing and make your opponent wait until your timer ticks down, which is terribly antisocial. 9. Server frequently kicks you out, and of course your game continues to tick down.

I think I've played every version of this game released for Android, and 
this is definitely the best so far. Not because of the 3D graphics, 
although they are nice, but because the design and gameplay have been honed 
to near-perfection. Some stuff in previous versions has been eliminated, 
some of it slightly altered (for the better!--for instance, the previously 
clunky River expansion), and some new features added. Among the new 
features, the addition of a Fields overlay is a godsend. It all but 
eliminates the tedium and the considerable confusion that tended to reign 
without it. Beyond that, the interface is clean and complete, and there are 
no intrusive ads. One of the available expansions is free--the Abbot, which 
is, arguably, the best of the three--but the other two are fairly pricey, 
imho, at three bucks each. Still, the game is good enough that I don't 
regret buying them, and I would recommend this game unreservedly to anyone 
who has an interest in it.
